name: Multiple mixed operations with compound fractions

skills.name: Complete multi-step fraction calculations including calculating with dollars

explanations.A: Mixing the milk chocolate and dark chocolate gets 5/4 cup and each cookie use 1/8 cup so we do 5/4 ÷ 1/8 = 5/4 x 8/1 = 10. Therefore 10 cookies can be glazed!
explanations.B: You have correctly added the milk chocolate and dark chocolate together, so there is 1 1/4 cup of glaze. Each cookie uses 1/8 cup of glaze... So how many cookies can be glazed?
explanations.C: You have correctly added the milk chocolate and dark chocolate together, but then I think you have added the 1/8 too. We want to know how many 1/8s are in 1 1/4 so we divide...
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied by 1/8 but we need to find out how many 1/8s are in 1 1/4, so we divide!

explanations.A: You have correctly added the white and dark chocolate together but then I think you have added the 1/6 too. We want to know how many 1/6s are in 1 1/12, so we divide...
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied by 1/6, but we need to find out how many 1/6s are in 1 1/12, so we divide!
explanations.C: Mixing the white and dark chocolate gets 13/12 cup and each cookie use 1/6 cup so we do 13/12 ÷ 1/6 = 13/12 x 6/1 = 6 1/2. Therefore 6 1/2 cookies can be glazed!
explanations.D: You have correctly added the white and dark chocolate together so there is 1 1/12 cup of glaze. Each cookie uses 1/6 cup of glaze... So how many cookies can be glazed?

explanations.A: This is the remaining lasagna we need to now cut into pieces 1/12 in size! How many 1/12 are in 4 and 1/4?
explanations.B: We have 5 pans of lasagna. We set aside 3/4 of a pan so now there are 4 1/4 pans of lasagna that need cutting up into 1/12 pieces. 4 1/4 ÷ 1/12 = 17/4 ÷ 1/12 = 17/4 x 12/1 = 204/4 = 51. Therefore she made 51 pieces of lasagna!
explanations.C: I think you have done 5 divided by 1/12, but first you need to set aside 3/4 of a pan...
explanations.D: You have correctly subtracted the 3/4 from 5, but then we don't subtract 1/12. We want to find out how many 1/12s are in 4 1/4 so we divide!

explanations.A: I think you have done 7 divided by 1/8, but first you need to set aside 3/4 of a pan...
explanations.B: This is the remaining cornbread. We need to now cut into pieces 1/8 in size! How many 1/8s are in 6 and 1/4?
explanations.C: You have correctly subtracted the 3/4 from 7, but then we don't subtract 1/8. We want to find out how many 1/8s are in 6 1/4 so we divide!
explanations.D: We have 7 pans of cornbread. We set aside 3/4 of a pan so now there are 6 1/4 pans of cornbread that need cutting up into 1/8 pieces. 6 1/4 ÷ 1/8 = 25/4 ÷ 1/8 = 25/4 x 8/1 = 200/4 = 50. Therefore she made 50 pieces of cornbread!

explanations.A: You have made a great start subtracting the length of the TV from the wall. You now need to divide this value by 2 to find out how far from the edge of the wall the TV should be placed...
explanations.B: I think you have done your operations in the wrong order - first subtract the TV length and then divide by 2!
explanations.C: This is how many times the TV could be placed along the wall. To find out how far from one edge it should be placed subtract the length of the TV from the wall and divide by 2!
explanations.D: To find out how far from each end the TV should be placed, we do the length of the wall subtract the length of the TV and then divide this value by 2. 168 3/4 - 37 1/2 = 131 1/4. 131 1/4 ÷ 2 = 65 5/8!

explanations.A: To find out how far from each end the TV should be placed, we do the length of the wall subtract the length of the TV and then divide this value by 2. 172 1/2 - 43 3/4 = 128 3/4. 128 3/4 ÷ 2 = 64 3/8!
explanations.B: This is how many times the TV could be placed along the wall. To find out how far from one edge it should be placed subtract the length of the TV from the wall and divide by 2!
explanations.C: You have made a great start subtracting the length of the TV from the wall. You now need to divide this value by 2 to find out how far from the edge of the wall the TV should be placed...
explanations.D: I think you have done your operations in the wrong order - first subtract the TV length and then divide by 2!

explanations.A: We have 72 1/4 cup servings, how many cups is this? We know each batch uses 2 1/4 cups so how many batches can be made?
explanations.B: The 5 pound bag of flour contains 18 cup servings (72 x 1/4 = 18). Dividing the amount of flour by how much flour is needed for each batch gives 18 ÷ 2 1/4 = 8 therefore Benji can make 8 batches of bran muffins with all his flour!
explanations.C: I think you have done your division the wrong way round... We want to know how many 2 1/4 cup servings are in the 72/4 cup bag of flour!
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied but we want to find out how many 2 1/4 are in 72/4 so we divide!

explanations.A: I think you have done your division the wrong way round... We want to know how many 1 1/3 cup servings are in the 54/3 cup bag of sugar!
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied, but we want to find out how many 1 1/3 are in 54/3 so we divide!
explanations.C: The 5 pound bag of sugar contains 18 cup servings (54 x 1/3 = 18). Dividing the amount of sugar by how much sugar is needed for each batch gives 18 ÷ 1 1/3 = 18 ÷ 4/3 = 18 x 3/4 = 13 1/2 therefore Liam can make 13 1/2 batches of blueberry muffins with all his sugar!
explanations.D: We have 54 1/3 cup servings, how many cups is this? We know each batch uses 1 1/3 cups so how many batches can be made?

explanations.A: I think you have accidentally divided the number of batches by the cost of the sugar but you need to do the cost divided by the number of batches!
explanations.B: This would be the cost of sugar per pound but we want the cost of sugar per batch!
explanations.C: There are 75 1/3 cup servings in a bag of sugar so this is (75 x 1/3) 25 cups in one bag. Each batch of cookies uses 1 2/3 (5/3) cup so 25 ÷ 5/3 = 25 x 3/5 = 15. This is how many batches can be made. The final step to work out the cost per batch is to do the cost of the bag of sugar divided by the number of batches that can be made: 5.87 ÷ 15 = 0.3913333... so $0.39!
explanations.D: We wouldn't make 45 batches... How many cup servings are in the bag of sugar if there are 75 1/3 cup servings?

explanations.A: This would be the cost of flour per pound but we want the cost of flour per batch!
explanations.B: There are 144 1/4 cup servings in a bag of flour so this is (144 x 1/4) 36 cups in one bag. Each batch of muffins uses 2 1/4 (9/4) cup so 36 ÷ 9/4 = 36 x 4/9 = 16. This is how many batches can be made. The final step to work out the cost per batch is to do the cost of the bag of flour divided by the number of batches that can be made: 4.39 ÷ 16 = 0.2743... so $0.27!
explanations.C: We wouldn't make 64 batches... How many cup servings are in the bag of flour if there are 144 1/4 cup servings?
explanations.D: I think you have accidentally divided the number of batches by the cost of the flour, but you need to do the cost divided by the number of batches!
